{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3322978,"name":"Johnathon","username":"Upcoming","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/u/a5b964/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-04T02:46:22.201Z","cooked":"

My team has been having issues shooting into the speaker from a distance due to the shaking of our arm. We have the shooter mounted to the bot using an axle driven by 2 sprockets each chained to a vortex motor at a 1 to 60 gear ratio. We can not think of a way to reduce the shaking mechanically without doing a complete redesign so I was wondering if there was a way to reduce it code wise or account for it when shooting.

Can you share a link to your code and a picture of your arm? Is there any way you’re measuring the angle of your arm programmatically?

I can‘t send an image right now but it looks like this

image3024×4032 2.49 MB

We use an absolute encoder to determine the position of the arm and the arm goes to the right angle with only a little shaking at the base but the problem is that at the end of the shooter the shaking is exacerbated and we don’t have a way to account for it.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2024-03-04T02:55:32.655Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":147,"readers_count":146,"score":44.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":457126,"topic_slug":"account-for-arm-shaking-in-code","display_username":"Johnathon","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/d/a/da485491ac0067908f4f44218cc5e6edb7688e91.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":53784,"username":"Max_Morehead","name":"Max Morehead","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/max_morehead/{size}/231937_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49222,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"tired"},"post_url":"/t/account-for-arm-shaking-in-code/457126/3","custom_user_title":"tired","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3322990,"name":"Tinnittin","username":"Tinnittin","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tinnittin/{size}/148604_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-04T02:56:14.650Z","cooked":"

It sounds like your issue is backlash. A very easy way to reduce this is preloading the backlash to one side of the mechanism. You can use a piece of elastic like surgical tubing, or a constant force spring to pull the arm to one end of the backlash. This will reduce the bouncing of the arm.

I thought we could try that but we have the shooter do large motions past 180 degrees so the surgical tubing would have to be strong enough to keep it stable while also not hindering it’s motion.

It’s hard to give good advice without more details. There are mechanical things you can do to improve the shaking, namely improving the mechanisms stiffness. 971 has a good presentation about stiffness: https://youtu.be/VNfFn-gcfFI?si=12hjH_De4d2vMDXf&t=1800 (starting at 30:00), though it’s a bit advanced. The main takeaways are make sure your chains are well-tensioned, use a higher gear ratio, use a bigger sprocket on your arm, prefer #35 to # 25 chain, decrease backlash in gears, increase the height of your arm beams, depending on your specific mechanism. In your case, you could probably benefit from increasing your gearing; 60:1 is quite low for an arm. You might also not have considered adding gas springs to counterbalance the arm.

There’s also a variety of things that you could do in code, namely use the motor actively to keep the arm still, but you’d have to provide more info about how you’re currently controlling the arm.

Max_Morehead:

You might also not have considered adding gas springs to counterbalance the arm.

This.

Whatever is cheap and close to the correct force/stroke.

They work brilliantly as a spring and a shock absorber.

One end in your frame, other in the arm sprocket.

2023 had more than a few teams use this approach.
